The fourth is the extensive explanation of the objects, which is also divided into two parts: first, the explanation of the various objects; second, the discussion of the similarities and differences among the various objects. The explanation of the objects is divided into six parts: first, the objects of the ten suchnesses; second, the objects of causes and conditions; third, the objects of the four truths;
fourth, the objects of the two truths;
fifth, the objects of the three truths;
sixth, the objects of the one truth.
However, the various sutras respond to conditions and clarify the objects in many ways, how could they be fully recorded?
Six kinds are briefly mentioned.
As for the sequence of the six kinds, the ten suchnesses are explained in this sutra, so they come first.
Next are the twelve links of dependent origination, which revolve through the three periods of time and originally possess everything.
When the Tathagata appeared in the world, he skillfully revealed the four truths with distinctions.ğŸ”½From broad to concise, the two truths are explained next.
The two truths are commonly used, but the middle way is specifically revealed, so the three truths are explained next.
The three truths still involve skillful means, directly revealing the true reality, next clarifying the one truth.
The one truth still has names and characteristics, next clarifying the non-truth.
Beginning from ignorance and ending at the ultimate reality, briefly using six kinds of feet.
First, clarifying the realm of the ten suchnesses, as already explained above.
Second, explaining the conditioned arising realm.
There are also four parts:
First, the correct explanation.ğŸ”½Second, the discrimination of the coarse and the subtle.

Fourth, clarifying the inconceivable non-arising and non-ceasing twelve links of dependent origination.
The two kinds of conceivable dependent origination are for the two kinds of conditions of sharpness and dullness, discussing the dharmas within the [three] realms.
The Madhyamaka Treatise says:
For the sake of dull-witted disciples, he spoke of the arising and ceasing characteristics of the twelve links of dependent origination.
This distinguishes it from non-Buddhist teachings;

Non-Buddhists wrongly believe that all dharmas are born from the creator god, some say from the nature of the world, some from atoms, some from parents, some from no cause, various wrong speculations that do not accord with reason.

This correct dependent origination is different from wrong speculations, it is only the various actions created in the past by the mind of ignorance and delusion, which can produce the good and bad fruits of suffering in the six realms of this world.
The Sutra of Right Mindfulness says:
A painter distributes the five colors, and depicts all forms, with countless degrees of beauty and ugliness.
Tracing back to the root, it comes from the painter's hand. The distinctions in the six realms are not made by the creator god, etc., they all come from a single thought of ignorance.
Ignorance, when combined with the highest level of evil actions, gives rise to the causes and conditions of hell, like the painter producing black color.

Ignorance combined with middling evil karma creates the causes and conditions for the animal realm, like drawing out the color red.ğŸ”½Ignorance combined with inferior evil karma creates the causes and conditions for the ghost realm, like drawing the color blue.
Ignorance combined with inferior good karma creates the causes and conditions for the asura realm, like drawing the color yellow.
Ignorance combined with middling good karma creates the causes and conditions for the human realm, like drawing the color white.
Ignorance combined with superior good karma creates the causes and conditions for the heavenly realm, like drawing the color of the highest white.

One should know that because ignorance combines with various karmic activities, there are the six destinies, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, old age, sickness, death, and so forth, with distinctions in superior, middling, and inferior.
The realms of humans and gods have myriad levels of suffering and joy. From birth one returns to death, and after death one is born again. The three times revolve like a spinning wheel of fire.
Therefore, the sÅ«tra says:
There is a whirlpool that drowns sentient beings, blinded by ignorance, unable to escape.
The sutra is also called the twelve links that bind each other, also called the twelvefold city, also called the twelve thorny gardens.
These twelve links of dependent origination are newly born and extinguished, moment by moment, not abiding, thus it is called the twelve links of dependent origination of birth and cessation.
As for the analysis, the fourth chapter of the Sutra of the Bodhisattva Stages says:
Ignorance conditions formations, giving rise to twelve, up to birth conditioning old age and death, also giving rise to twelve, thus there are one hundred and twenty links of dependent origination.
The first is delusion, up to old age and death is also delusion.
Because of non-enlightenment, it is delusion. The beginning is also non-enlightenment, up to old age and death is also non-enlightenment;
Because of delusion, there is birth, because of delusion, there is death.

If one can be enlightened to dependent origination, dependent origination will not operate. Because delusion does not operate, then future birth and death will end, which is called wisdom. Wisdom is in accordance with the Way.
Also, are the twelve links of dependent origination and the twelve links of dependent arising the same or different?
This is the same as all conditioned dharmas, so there is no difference.

There are also distinctions. The cause is dependent origination, and the effect is dependent arising. Then there are two dependent originations, five dependent arisings, three dependent originations, and two dependent arisings.
Moreover, ignorance is dependent origination, and action is dependent arising, up to birth being dependent origination, and old age and death being dependent arising.
There are also four phrases:

Dependent arising that is not dependent origination is the two past links and the final death aggregates of the present arhat.
Dependent origination and dependent arising are all past and present dharmas except for the five aggregates of death of the past and present arhats.
That which is neither dependent origination nor dependent arising are the unconditioned dharmas.
The Dharma Body Sutra says:
All the definite arising of ignorance produces formations, inseparable, always following each other, this is called dependent origination, not dependent arising.
If ignorance does not definitely produce formations, sometimes separated, not following each other, this is called dependent arising, not dependent origination.
Up to old age and death is also like this.
The Venerable Vasumitra said:
This is dependent origination, dharmas born from causes are dependent arising;
combination is dependent origination, born from combination is dependent arising.
The twelve links of dependent origination, two are past and stop permanence, two are future and stop annihilation, and the present manifests the middle way.
Investigating the three causes in the present, it is said that there are two fruits in the future;
investigating the five fruits in the present, it is said that there are two causes in the past.
The three periods of time all have the twelve links, in order to investigate causes and effects, it is said in this way.
As for the twelve times, ignorance is the time of past bonds.
Action refers to the time of past actions.
Consciousness refers to the time of the continuous mind and its associated factors.
Name-and-form refers to the time after rebirth has occurred and the continuity has begun, but the four kinds of form faculties have not yet developed, and the six sense bases are not yet complete.

Six sense bases refers to the time when the four kinds of form faculties have already developed and the six sense bases are complete.
These faculties are not yet able to serve as the basis for contact, and this period is called six sense bases.

These faculties are already able to serve as the basis for contact, but have not yet distinguished between pleasure and pain, and are unable to avoid danger, such as touching fire, poison, or a blade, and are impure, and this period is called contact.

It can distinguish between suffering and pleasure, avoid dangers, etc., can give rise to craving and love, but does not give rise to sexual desire, and does not become attached to anything. At this time, it is called feeling.
When the above three feelings are present, it is called craving.
Because of craving for objects, one pursues in all directions. At this time, it is called grasping.
When pursuing, one gives rise to body, speech, and mind. At this time, it is called existence.
Just as the present consciousness is in the future, at this time, it is called birth.
Just as the present name-and-form, six sense bases, contact, and feeling are in the future, at this time, it is called old age and death.
As for the twelve links in a single moment, if one kills out of a greedy mind, the corresponding ignorance is ignorance.
The corresponding thought is conditioning.
The corresponding mind is consciousness.
When there is action, there must be name-and-form.
When there is the arising of action, there must be the six sense bases.
The corresponding contact is contact.
The corresponding feeling is feeling.
Craving is precisely craving.
The corresponding entanglements are grasping.
The bodily and verbal actions are becoming.
The arising of these dharmas is birth.
The transformation of these dharmas is old age.
The destruction of these dharmas is death.
Question:
Why not speak of illness as a link?
Answer:
That which exists at all times and in all places is established as a link.
There are people who are born without illness, like Bakkula, who has never known a headache since birth, let alone other illnesses!
Therefore, it is not established.
Question:
Are sorrow and lamentation links or not?
Answer:
No, it is just the end revealing the beginning, like old age and death must be followed by sorrow and lamentation.
Question:
Does ignorance have a cause or not?
Does old age and death have a result or not?
If it exists, it should be a link.
If it does not exist, then it falls into the teaching of no cause and no effect.
Answer:
It exists but is not a link.
Ignorance has a cause, which is incorrect thought;
Old age and death have an effect, which is sorrow and lamentation.
Moreover, ignorance has a cause, which is old age and death;
Old age and death have an effect, which is ignorance.
The present craving and grasping are the past ignorance;
The present name-and-form, six sense bases, contact, and feeling, these four, if in the future, are called old age and death.
As it is said that feeling is the condition for craving, one should know that old age and death are the condition for ignorance.
It is like a cart wheel, mutually causing each other.
Those born from wombs in the desire realm have all twelve links.
Those in the form realm have eleven, lacking name-and-form.
The formless realm has ten, excluding name-and-form and the six sense bases.
It is also said that they have all.
When one is first born in the form realm, before the faculties become sharp, this is called name-and-form.
Although there is no form in the formless realm, one should know that all twelve links are present.
Question:

Answer:
The differences are past, present, and new, having already given results, not yet given results, and so on.
Second, the twelve links of non-arising and non-cessation through contemplation: this uses skillful means to refute the crude.

The mind's activities created by improper thought are like a magician in the four crossroads, conjuring up various elephants, horses, necklaces, people, etc. The deluded consider them real, but the wise know they are not true.
Ignorance conjures up the six destinies of the dependent and the independent; one should know they are originally non-existent, created by ignorance.
If one knows the vine is originally not a snake, then the fearful mind does not arise. Since it does not arise, it does not cease.
This is called the inconceivable arising and ceasing of the twelve links of dependent origination.

Third, the inconceivable arising and ceasing of dependent origination breaks down the small and reveals the great, and is taught for the sake of both sharp and dull faculties regarding the teachings outside the three realms.
The Huayan Sutra says:
The mind is like a skilled painter, creating the various five skandhas.
In all worlds, there is nothing that is not created by the mind.
The painter refers to the ignorant mind.
All worlds refers to the provisional and real lands of the ten dharma realms.
The various treatises clarify that the mind gives rise to all dharmas differently. Some say:
The Älaya is the true consciousness, from which all dharmas arise.
Some say:
The Älaya is the non-perishing consciousness, and non-defiled ignorance gives rise to all dharmas.
If one definitely grasps at the true nature, one falls into the error of the primordial origin of consciousness and the arising of the mind of self from consciousness.
One cannot even establish the conceivable causes and conditions within the [three] realms, let alone establish the inconceivable causes and conditions outside the [three] realms.
Since delusion is not an inconceivable object, how can the understanding that overturns delusion become inconceivable wisdom?
The refutation of this is explained in the ÅšamathavipaÅ›yanÄ.
Now, it is clarified that the mind of ignorance is not self, not other, not shared, and not without cause. The four propositions are all inconceivable.
If there are the causes and conditions of the four siddhÄntas, it can also be said:
Just as a dream cannot be found when sought in the four ways, yet it is said that one sees all things in a dream;
The four propositions are used to seek ignorance, which cannot be found, yet from ignorance, all dharmas within and outside the realms arise.
The twelve links of dependent origination outside the realms are as explained above.
As for the twelve links of dependent origination outside the realms, the Bao Xing Lun says:
The empty wisdom of arhats and pratyekabuddhas has never seen the fundamental nature of the Tathagata's body.
Although the two vehicles have the four antidotes such as impermanence, based on the Tathagata's Dharma body, they are still inverted. Because of inversion, they are ignorance.
There are four kinds of obstacles in abiding in the undefiled realm, namely conditions, characteristics, birth, and destruction.
Conditions refer to the ground of ignorance, which serves as a condition for karmic activity.
Characteristics refer to ignorance and karmic activity being causes together.
Birth refers to the ground of ignorance, which together with undefiled karma, gives rise to the three kinds of mind-made bodies.
Destruction refers to the three kinds of mind-made bodies, which are conditioned by inconceivable transformation death.
It is like the twelve links of dependent origination within the realm, from ignorance to old age and death.
Condition refers to the link of ignorance.
Appearance refers to the link of karmic formations.
Birth refers to the five links of name-and-form and so forth.
The three links of craving, grasping, and becoming can be understood by analogy with the previous.
Destruction refers to the link of birth and death.
These twelve links have the same number as those within the realm, but their meanings are greatly different.
That treatise states:
The three kinds of mind-born bodies have not yet attained freedom from the defilements of ignorance, have not yet attained the ultimate undefiled purity;
The subtle conceptual proliferation of ignorance has not been eternally extinguished, they have not yet attained the ultimate undefiled self;

The accumulation of the subtle conceptual proliferation of ignorance, the mind-born aggregates caused by pure karma have not yet been eternally extinguished, they have not yet attained the bliss of the unconditioned;
The defilements of afflictions, the defilements of karma, and the defilements of birth have not yet been ultimately extinguished, they have not yet realized the ultimate permanence of the nectar.
Because of the condition of the path of afflictions, they do not attain great purity;
Because of the characteristics of the path of karma, one does not attain the eight kinds of self-mastery;
Because of the suffering of birth, one does not attain great bliss;
Because of the decay of old age and death, one does not attain the unchanging and eternal. This is due to the inconceivable arising and ceasing of the twelve links of dependent origination.
This is the inconceivable arising and ceasing of the twelve links of dependent origination outside the three realms.
As for the inconceivable twelve links of dependent origination that are neither arising nor ceasing, it is for the sake of those with sharp faculties to reveal the principle through phenomena.

Action and becoming are the path of karma, which is precisely liberation. Liberation is self-mastery, which is the buddha-nature of the conditional cause.
Name-and-form and old age and death are the path of suffering, and suffering is precisely the Dharma body.
The Dharma body is without suffering and without joy, and this is called great joy.
Not born and not dying is permanence, the true cause of Buddha-nature.
Therefore it is said that between ignorance and craving, this is precisely the middle way.

Ignorance is the past, and craving is the present. Whether on the edge or in the middle, there is nothing that is not Buddha-nature, and all are permanent, joyful, self, and pure. Ignorance does not arise and is also not extinguished.
This is called the inconceivable non-arising and non-extinction of the twelve links of dependent arising.
Second, in distinguishing the coarse and subtle, the realm of dependent arising should not be coarse or subtle. It is only due to the shallowness or depth of grasping it that there are differences.

If it is said that from ignorance arise the various activities up to old age and death, from three arise two, from two arise seven, from seven arise three, mutually causing each other, the causes and conditions of afflictions and karma, the causes and conditions of karma and suffering, impermanence and arising and ceasing,

This sutra:

Therefore, we know that this realm is coarse.

The Nirvana Sutra says that by extinguishing ignorance, one can attain the blazing [fire].
This sutra is the great tree that can grow.
Compared to what came before, it is wonderful; compared to what comes after, it is coarse.
If one says:

This sutra:

Third, revealing the coarse and manifesting the wonderful, as the sutra says:

My Dharma is wonderful and difficult to conceive. The previous three are all the Buddha's Dharma. How could there be a coarse that can be conceived, different from the wonderful that cannot be conceived?
There is no explanation of the meaning of liberation apart from words. It is just that the essence of what can be conceived is the inconceivable.
It is like a wealthy man who provides poor people with basins, utensils, rice, and flour, making them the property of the poor people.

The mind moment after moment abides within the secret treasury, always giving rise to this contemplation, called relying on the holy embryo.

The accumulation [of causes] is truly the cause, there is no other cause.
The path that ends suffering is truly the path.
These all clarify the characteristics of the four noble truths of arising and cessation.

Because the characteristics of suffering are coarse, it is explained first. Although cessation is not true, because cessation leads to the true, the coarse characteristics of cessation are also explained first.

As for the one without an agent, because delusion is light in the middle, it gets its name from principle.

There are skillful means in accordance with sentient beings, speaking of the two truths.

However, in the ÅšrÄ«mÄlÄ-sÅ«tra, it is said that among the four noble truths without fabrication, the truth of cessation alone is the ultimate of the Buddha, is permanent, is true, and is the basis, while the other three are impermanent, are not true, and are not the basis.

DharmatrÄta refutes this argument, saying:

Second, to clarify the two truths, I will briefly point out the essence of reality as the truth of ultimate reality, and ignorance and the twelve links of dependent arising as the truth of conventional reality. This is sufficient in meaning.

How much more so for the subsequent expositions of the truths, which are far beyond the text and not within the scope of worldly emotions.
As for the seven kinds of two truths, the first is that real existence is conventional;

The two truths of illusory existence and emptiness and non-emptiness.

If one is able to diligently cultivate the foundations of mindfulness and give rise to the four wholesome roots, at that time the two truths that follow emotions are all called the conventional;

One can then speak of following emotions, emotions and wisdom, and wisdom equally, of entering the common and the distinct, entering the common and the perfect, causing them to be ashamed of the small and yearn for the great, to feel pity for their ruined seeds, and to thirst for the supreme vehicle.

The mind gradually becomes open and at ease. One can then speak of the distinct and the perfect, entering the distinct, clarifying the unique prajÃ±Ä, and entrusting with the family business. Gold, silver, and precious treasures, all buying and selling, are made to be known.

The one flavor of ghee is then subtle.
